ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General knowledge of ship and submarine systems, especially those dealing with electrical and power management, were strengthened, as well as overall ship design and administrative structure.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The biggest strength was having the 20+ years of experience provided by the instructor, specifically including years from his enlistment as a Machinist-Mate on submarines. Alongside the general approachability and overall organization of the class, there weren't any weaknesses I can think of outside of the lack of Yale credit for the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, if you have any interest in ship design and how the United States Navy structures it's vessels, you should take this class. Again, hard to recommend to non-NROTC students due to the lack of Yale class credit.
